prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CII 158
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the CII line at 0.16" resolution (~1.2kpc scale in source plane). Flux limits have been identified assuming a [CII]/FIR = 0.1%, diluted over 30 beams over the source to be detected within a 50 km/s bin at minimum 3 sigma. Due to minimum overheads for high frequency observations, we use a minimum integration time of 11 minutes here. Continuum sensitivity is based on Herschel PACS & SPIRE photometry.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given our estimate of sensitivity in a 50 km/s bin, we keep a spectral resolution element closest to ~10km/s around the line across our observations. In this case it is also the lowest possible spectral resolution.

A native (gaussian) deconvolution of the 880 micron SMA imaging suggests a source size ~0.55". A beam size of 0.16" at the distance of the source provides a spatial resolution of ~1.2kpc. For the simplistic worse case situation, we have assumed that the source is uniformly spread over 30 beams to calculate the sensitivity requirements. We use the largest recoverable angular scale as 2.25" to make sure we are not losing emission from extended structure in the source.

Typical observed line widths of the [CII] line are a few hundred km/s in galaxies. We estimate the [CII] line luminosity based on its non detection in the the Herschel-SPIRE spectra and comparing it to the Far-IR luminosity of the system. Using a starburst like ratio of [CII]/FIR = 0.1%, we calculate the expected line flux. We use a resolution element of 50km/s to calculate the required rms sensitivity so as to be able to resolve and detect the line in 4 spectral channels (assuming 200km/s line width). Integrated over the line width the detection would be >5-sigma in each beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: OIII 88
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the OIII88 micron line at 0.16" resolution (~1.2kpc scale in source plane). Flux limits have been identified using the ZEUS-2 detection F[OIII] ~3.3e-18 W m-2, diluted over 30 beams over the source to be detected within a 50 km/s bin at minimum 3 sigma in each beam.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given our estimate of sensitivity in a 50 km/s bin, we keep a spectral resolution element closest to ~10km/s around the line across our observations. In this case it is also the lowest possible spectral resolution.

A native (gaussian) deconvolution of the 880 micron SMA imaging suggests a source size ~0.55". A beam size of 0.16" at the distance of the source provides a spatial resolution of ~1.2kpc. For the simplistic worse case situation, we have assumed that the source is uniformly spread over 30 beams to calculate the sensitivity requirements. We use 2.4" for the largest recoverable angular scale as that contains all of the imaging area possible for this observation.

Our ZEUS-2 observation of the 88 micron line at R~800 suggests a line width of ~500km/s, which should be an over estimation of the total line width due to coarse resolution. We use a resolution element of 50km/s to calculate the required rms sensitivity so as to be able to resolve and detect the line in 4 binned spectral channels (assuming 200km/s line width). Integrated over the line width the detection would be >5-sigma in each beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: NII 205
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the NII line at 0.16" resolution (~1.2kpc scale in source plane) Flux limits have been identified assuming a [CII]/FIR~0.1% and [CII]/[NII] ~ 25, diluted over 30 beams over the source to be detected within a 50 km/s bin at minimum 3 sigma.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given our estimate of sensitivity in a 50 km/s bin, we keep a spectral resolution element closest to ~10km/s around the line across our observations. The continuum SPWs are read out at the lowest possible resolution.

A native (gaussian) deconvolution of the 880 micron SMA imaging suggests a source size ~0.55". A beam size of 0.16" at the distance of the source provides a spatial resolution of ~1.2kpc. For the simplistic worse case situation, we have assumed that the source is uniformly spread over 30 beams to calculate the sensitivity requirements. We use the largest recoverable angular scale as 2.25" to make sure we are not losing emission from extended structure in the source.

[NII] could be coming from a more concentrated region of ionized gas as opposed to the extended [CII] emission showing few hundred km/s line widths. So the observed line width could be smaller. We use a resolution element of 50km/s to calculate the required rms sensitivity so as to be able to resolve and detect the line in 4 binned spectral channels (assuming 200km/s line width). Integrated over the line width the detection would be >5-sigma in each beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 5-4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the CO(5-4) line at 0.21" resolution (~1.6kpc scale in source plane). We assume the CO(5-4) line is atleast as bright as the observed CO(4-3) line at 4.26 Jy km s-1. Flux limits have been identified assuming dilution with 30 beams over the source to be detected within a 50 km/s bin at minimum 3 sigma.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given our estimate of sensitivity in a 50 km/s bin, we keep a spectral resolution element closest to ~10km/s around the line across our observations. The continuum SPWs are read out at the 2nd lowest possible resolution.

A native (gaussian) deconvolution of the 880 micron SMA imaging suggests a source size ~0.55". A beam size of 0.21" at the distance of the source provides a spatial resolution of ~1.6kpc. Choosing a slightly larger beam for this science goal heps avoid ~67% extra overhead time required when using the longest baselines (t_obs = 1.36h at 0.21" vs 2.27h at 0.2"). For the simplistic worse case situation, we have assumed that the source is uniformly spread over 30 beams to calculate the sensitivity requirements. We do not correct for the changed resolution element because the CO line may be more extended than the continuum or FIR lines. We use 3.5" for the largest recoverable angular scale to make sure we are not losing diffuse molecular gas emission from larger structure around the source.

Assuming the (5-4) transition is as bright as the (4-3) transition, we use the observed CO(4-3) measurement of ~4.3Jy km/s in a 4" beam to estimate our CO(5-4) flux with a resolution element of 50km/s to calculate the required rms sensitivity. We will be able to resolve and detect the line in 4 binned spectral channels (assuming 200km/s line width). Integrated over the line width the detection would be >5-sigma in each beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 8-7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map the CO(8-7) line at 0.16" resolution (~1.2kpc scale in source plane). We assume the CO(8-7) line is half as bright as the observed CO(4-3) line at 4.26 Jy km s-1. Flux limits have been identified assuming dilution with 12 beams over the source to be detected within a 50 km/s bin at minimum 3 sigma.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Given our estimate of sensitivity in a 50 km/s bin, we keep a spectral resolution element closest to ~10km/s around the line across our observations. The continuum SPWs are read out at the lowest possible resolution.

A native (gaussian) deconvolution of the 880 micron SMA imaging suggests a source size ~0.55". A beam size of 0.16" at the distance of the source provides a spatial resolution of ~1.2kpc. For the simplistic worse case situation, we have assumed that the source is uniformly spread over 30 beams to calculate the sensitivity requirements. We use 2.25" for the largest recoverable angular scale to make sure we are not losing diffuse emission from larger structure around the source.

Assuming the (8-7) transition is half as bright as the (4-3) transition, we use the CO(4-3) line flux to estimate the CO(8-7) flux, with a resolution element of 50km/s to calculate the required rms sensitivity. We will be able to resolve and detect the line in 4 binned spectral channels (assuming 200km/s line width). Integrated over the line width the detection would be >5-sigma in each beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high resolution (0.2"~1.5 kpc) mapping of a compact HyLIRG at z~3, tracing the [OIII] 88um, [CII] 158um, [NII] 205um far-IR lines along with molecular gas emission from CO(5-4) and CO(8-7) transitions. HATLAS113526.3-14605, hereafter G12H43, is one of the brightest sub-mm sources in the sky with L(IR)=1.2x10E14 L(Solar) which is assumed to be due to strong lensing. However, there is no detection of a foreground lens and the source is only marginally resolved with ~0.7" SMA imaging at 880um. Our proposed observations would help create a resolved map of dust, gas and far-IR line emission, distinguish the energy source powering its luminosity, unravel lensed images (if any) and study kinematics and spatial distribution of the neutral, ionized and molecular gas. We will be able to test star formation laws in kpc scale regions of active star-formation, use line ratios to constrain the ambient FUV field, metallicity and age of the most recent starburst. With the available measurements of CO(1-0),(3-2) and (4-3) lines, we would be able to comprehensively study the CO excitation ladder putting in context the physical properties of the interstellar medium of G12H43.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Nucleo de Astronomia, Universidad Diego Portales
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
Center for Radiophysics and Space Research, Cornell University
Submillimeter Astrophysics Group, California Institute of Technology
